msIdentifier.collection: Historical Society of Pennsylvania cartoons and caricatures collection

history.acquisition: This is an artificial collection created over time by HSP staff mostly through donations and purchases of individual prints. It also incorporates previously uncataloged materials collected by the Balch Institute for Ethnic Studies. Some of the 20th century cartoons and drawings were removed from the J. Hampton Moore papers (Collection 1541)."

monogr.title: The Man That Blocks Up the Highway

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.
This xml file uses unique entity identifiers, media file identifiers, and collection identifiers in HSP's Digital Library, available at http://digitallibrary.hsp.org.

div.p: Men driving carriages labeled "Freedmen's Bureau," "Civil Rights," and "Reconstruction" find their road blocked by a large log labeled "Veto." In front of the roadblock stands US president Andrew Johnson, who in 1865 vetoed the Civil Rights Act (it eventually passed in spite of his veto) and pardoned former Confederates who swore allegiance to the United States. In 1866, Johnson also vetoed an updated version of a bill to authorize the Freedmen's Bureau, which was established in 1865 to aid and protect the rights of freed slaves. Johnson, standing at the center of the image, is depicted with donkey ears. He describes the carriage drivers as "Radical Republicans" and shakes the hand of a man he has pardoned for counterfeiting. At left, former Confederate soldiers shake their fists at the men driving the carriages as they boast of killing Union officers during the Civil War, threaten to whip and collar the Northerners, and declare loyalty to Johnson. Vice president William Seward, standing behind the Johnson, pours whiskey for the Southerners. At right, Emperor Napoleon III of France puts his arm around John Bull, symbolizing Great Britain, and expresses admiration for Johnson. Boxes of pardons and political appointments for Southerners stand at Napoleon and John Bull's feet. Behind the roadblock, the carriage drivers discuss ancient Roman tribunes, elected representatives of the people's rights. This cartoon criticizes Johnson's leniency toward the South in the aftermath of the Civil War, which many Northerners viewed as a betrayal, and his opposition to Radical Republican goals of assisting former slaves and ensuring equal rights for Americans, regardless of race.

p.hi: THE MAN THAT BLOCKS UP THE HIGHWAY.

div.p: J. L. MAGEE, PUBLISHER, SOUTH-EAST CORNER THIRD AND DOCK STS., PHILAD'A
I murdered one Major-General, and have just been pardoned. I've got two more Generals and a dozen others spotted, and as soon as I get home they go under the sod "That's so!"

You d—d Yankee hounds, just wait 'til we take our seats,—we'll give you Civil Rights—with the skin of a Cow, and an iron collar round your necks. We used the Lion's skin once, we'll use the Fox's next, and you'll find a live Tiger concealed in the folds. We'll tear your cursed hearts out. Andy's working all right for us. We're loyal now. Ha! Ha! Ha!

I'm eternally obliged to you, Andy, for the Pardon you granted me. I made Fifty Thousand Dollars on that last batch of counterfeits for which I was convicted. I'll make a Hundred Thousand on the next lot. You kin bet on my vote, ole Pal!

This way, Gentlemen, this way, I am happy to take you by the hand. Billy, hand around the whisky,—as to you Radical Republicans, not one of you shall pass over this road until you have first prostrated yourselves in the dust, and on bended knee, and with bated breath, offered up this prayer—Andy Johnson is Great, and the Veto is his Prophet!—that's my Policy
Them old ROMAN TRIBUTES was Great Men! Was n't they?

Yes, Great Scoundrels, the most of them. Mark Antony was one of them, and while he was continually blowing before the People about his great love for the Constitution, he was conspiring with Caesar for the overthrow of the Republic, and finally succeeded. These Tribunes will bear watching.
Vive La Andre John'Stone! Vive La Emperor!! I am ze French Emperor, I have no Senate, no House. You shall have no Senate, no House. You shall be ze Emperor Americane! Vive La Emperor!!
ANDY JOHNSON, Tribune of the People
William Seward, Andrew Johnson's vice president, pours whiskey into a mug to serve to the Southerners. A jug of liquor and a picnic basket containing another bottle lie at his feet.

Emperor Napoleon III of France and John Bull, symbolizing Great Britain, look admiringly at Andrew Johnson. Britain and France, to varying extents, were supportive of the Confederacy during the Civil War.
